paragraphs.body: Writing in the Avatar World is achieved through several means. This is primarily through the use of brush, ink and paper; however, there are also engravings. The actual written language is in Chinese or Hanzi, with thousands of characters made up of different kinds of strokes, and is usually written top down or right to left, though this is not always the case.

paragraphs.body: Calligraphy is a form of art where one writes, or rather, draws or paints characters in a particularly artistic way to emphasize its beauty and shape. The paper, ink, brush, and inkstone are essential implements in calligraphy. paragraphs.body: The set of Chinese characters featured in Avatar is predominantly traditional, used regularly in modern Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau, as well as older overseas Chinese communities. Many characters were simplified in the 20th century as part of a literacy campaign by the Chinese Communist party and are used in Mainland China, Singapore, Malaysia and by the United Nations. Readers should note that contrary to popular belief, most Chinese characters are not stylized representations of pictures, that is, most characters are not pictograms. Though many of the characters once were pictograms, centuries of change has rendered the resemblance almost non-existent.
